titleStmt.title: John of Ephesus, Zeʿora, in The Lives of the Eastern Saints

listBibl.head: Sources for the Data in this Born Digital Prosopography

bibl.title: Lives of the Eastern Saints I
Zeʿora

event.desc: Zeʿora miraculously restored a spring that had stopped flowing

person.persName: The monk who witnessed the miracle performed by Zeʿora

personGrp.persName: The persons who gathered together to be blessed by Zeʿora

event.desc: The Huns arrived and threatened Zeʿora, probably in 515.

div.note:
This date is suggested in a footnote by Brooks.
19

event.desc: Zeʿora miraculously stopped a Hun from killing him, probably in 515.

div.note:
This date is suggested in a footnote by Brooks.
19

personGrp.persName: A mighty hosts of the Huns

person.persName: The Hun barbarian who tried to kill Zeʿora

event.desc: The master of Zeʿora died.
Zeʿora made a column for himself and stood on it.
From atop his column Zeʿora healed the sick by blessing water and sprinkling it on them.
Chalcedonian persecutors removed Zeʿora from his column.
Zeʿora took ten disciples and traveled to Constantinople in order to protest the treatment of the non-Chalcedonians to the emperor

personGrp.persName: The ten disciples who followed Zeʿora to Constantinople

event.desc: The persecutors of Zeʿora sent letters to Constantinople to explain their treatment of Zeʿora.
The emperor opposed Zeʿora who spoke boldly in defense of his non-Chalcedonian convictions and against the persecution of non-Chalcedonians. The emperor oppossed Zeʿora but also feared him.
Zeʿora anathematized the Council of Chalcedon and inflicted the emperor with swelling and a compromised mental state.

personGrp.persName: The magistrates who witnessed the encounter between Zeʿora and Justinian

event.desc: Justinian fell ill and Theodora hid him while she convinced Zeʿora to heal the emperor.

personGrp.persName: The intercessors who were sent to fetch Zeʿora

event.desc: Zeʿora restored Justinian to health and the emperor relented from pusuing strict persecution of non-Chalcedonians.
Zeʿora's fame grew, extending as far as the city of Rome and enabling him to have great influence among the emperor and the senators. He used this influence to care for the poor.
Pope Agapetus, who was about to blaspheme by declaring that Mary should not be commemorated in the church, urged the emperor to expel Zeʿora.

occupation.note: Agapetus was the Patriarch of Rome

event.desc: Agapetus sent a message to Zeʿora at a villa near Sycae, demanding he obey Justinian. Zeʿora refused. Anonymous 3645 tried to bring him back to the city but heavy winds prevented him crossing the Golden Horn.

person.persName: The magister sent to arrest Zeʿora

event.desc: Agapetus died suddenly on the day predicted by Zeʿora and Anonymi 3646 accused him of using magic against the Pope.
Zeʿora engaged in affective prayer.
Zeʿora performed many acts of charity for the poor.
Zeʿora left the city to dwell in Alexandria .
Zeʿora died, leaving behind his disciple Hananya.

bibl.title: Lives of the Eastern Saints I
Zeʿora
